content.title: Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) Anatomy
content.definition: The anatomic confluence where the great saphenous vein enters the common femoral vein, including its tributaries, and the surgical landmark for GSV procedures.

anatomy.location: Approximately 3-4 cm inferior and lateral to pubic tubercle
anatomy.relationship: CFV lies lateral to CFA at this level

gsv_tributaries.variability: Significant anatomic variation in tributary pattern

terminal_valve.function: Prevents reflux from CFV into GSV
terminal_valve.significance: First valve to fail in primary varicose veins

surgical_anatomy.cribriform_fascia: Covers SFJ, contains hiatus for GSV

clinical_significance.reflux: SFJ incompetence drives most primary varicose veins
clinical_significance.ablation: Target for thermal or non-thermal ablation

clinical_pearls: SFJ is 3-4 cm below and lateral to pubic tubercle
Terminal valve failure = primary GSV reflux
Always identify tributaries before high ligation
